title: prestonpans-schools-pupils-aiming-get-involved-community
story: St Gabrielrsquos RC Primary School sent P representatives Olivia Lees, Ciaran Kelly, Fraser Graham, and Daniel McCabe, all , to speak to Prestonpans Community Council about their work and the potential involvement of much younger participants.The school was recently successful in achieving its UNICEF Rights Respecting School gold award, which means that it had proved that it incorporates the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child into the school through both teaching and actions.It now aims to take this further and bring this ethos into the surrounding community.The children were given the chance of addressing the meeting, which included ward councillors Fiona OrsquoDonnell and Neil Gilbert, to ask questions and discuss the best ways to engage young people with what is going on in the community and to ensure their input is noted.The children asked about the plans for the site of the former Cockenzie Power Station and whether more activities for young people such as Rainbows and Scouts could be introduced to the areaWhen addressing the councillors and community councillors, Daniel, a house captain from St Gabrielrsquos, said: ldquoItrsquos important for us at this stage to know what our future is going to hold, and to try and make a dference when and where we can.ldquoTo be involved in the community council in some way would be fantastic, as it would give us comfort to know that the community is being taken care of, as well as what decisions were being made that might affect us.It was decided that the community council would send the agenda for each meeting to the school a few days before the meeting took place so that the children could see it and comment on any issues being raised.The community council said in a statement: ldquoWe would like to thank the four fantastic pupils from St Gabrielrsquos Primary School who attended the community council.ldquoIt was so refreshing to have such polite and knowledgeable young people along to one of our meetings to share their opinions and views on our agenda topics and ask the questions they feel most relevant to their lives.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming them along to future meetings and collaborating with them on the issues that affect all of us living in Prestonpans.

title: fringe-sea-q-amp-professor-ben-garrod
story: The professor is a broadcaster, author and evolutionary biologist at the University of East Anglia and has done a QA to gear people up for his show.Were you interested in dinosaurs as a child Not just dinosaurs, but anything prehistoric. My first fossil find was on a beach near where I grew up. I was five years old and was on a day out with mum and dad. We wound the fossilised shell of a belemnite, which was a relative of the squid we see alive today. It was over  million years old and that blew my socks off! It made me start questioning where all these ancient animals went, why we donrsquot have dinosaurs around now and how the planet could be so old. Obviously, I loved dinosaurs too and loved reading about them in all my old books, imagining what it would be like to see a T. rex walking through my garden.Why are so many children obsessed with them So many people are obsessed with dinosaurs, both kids and adults alike. Itrsquos hard to pin down exactly why we love them so much and I think itrsquos for a few dferent reasons. First of all, when we are growing up we love to learn lots of facts about things . . . the speed of fast cars maybe or the size of planets in space. Dinosaurs are the same and we love to learn how fast an Allosaurus could run or discover which was the biggest. I also think they inspire us through being so big, fierce and scary but we feel safe because we know dinosaurs can never hurt us because theyrsquore all extinct You are described as an lsquoevolutionary biologistrsquo ndash what exactly does that entail Irsquom a Professor of Evolutionary Biology at the University of East Anglia. Sounds fancy doesnrsquot it but itrsquos the coolest job in the world. The lsquoBiologyrsquo bit just means I get to study all sorts of le ndash it could be anything that is alive or was ever alive, so anything from a chimpanzee or a Troodon, to a butterfly or monkey puzzle tree. The lsquoEvolutionrsquo bit means I study how these living organisms change and adapt over time. How does a changing marine environment affect sharks or how does predation from birds affect camouflage in lizards  All these changes are down to evolution. I study le and how it changes, and I share that knowledge with as many people as possible. Being a scientist means you get to study cool stuff like this every single day.How many books have you written I have written six books so far. My series lsquoSo You Think You Know About Dinosaursrsquo are pretty cool, evenI do say so myself. I wanted them to be the most up to date dinosaur books in  million years and although I wanted them to be enjoyed by young readers, the content should be the same as that which I teach to university students. I know young readers really want to learn and we donrsquot need to dumb stuff down, but with a few more cartoons, quizzes and examples, I think they can be enjoyed by young and older readers. Each book focuses on just one species and it was so hard to pick just six. Eventually, I chose Tyrannosaurus, Triceratops, Stegosaurus, Diplodocus, Velociraptor and Spinosaurus. Therersquos something there for everyone and between them, these dinosaurs really tell the complete story.Herersquos something we all want to know ndash which dinosaur would have been the most dangerous to humans Arrrrrgh, this is such a tough question. Is one T. rex worse than one hundred velociraptors  Even something like a Triceratops could have been deadly. Itrsquos easier to say which dinosaurs would have been safe . . . there wouldnrsquot have been many. Stegosaurus had tail spikes around one metre long, Ankylosaurus had a tail club which could have destroyed a car and Argentinosaurus weighed so much that yoursquod definitely want to be stepped on. And theyrsquore just the herbivores! Imagine what the meat-eaters would have done.And which was the very biggest Ah, this is a question I get asked a lot. There has been huge debate and even some arguments between scientists. Irsquom not going to give it away ndash yoursquoll have to come to my show and find out. Irsquoll give you a clue . . . itrsquos not the one you think it is.What dinosaurs would have roamed around this country many millions of years ago This is a really hard one to answer for each show right now. We had so many prehistoric species that wersquore spoilt for choice now. We had giant sauropods up on the Western Isles in Scotland, early relatives of T. rex in Wales and even the fish-eating Baryonyx on the Isle of Wight. There are also discoveries of marine reptiles such as the dolphin-like ichthyosaurs and super-predator pliosaurs all around our coastlines all the time. The best thing to do is get out there and go have a look or visit your local museum and discover what used to swim, fly, run and plod around near where you live, millions of years ago.Were numbers declining before whatever environmental catastrophe wiped them out about m years ago and would they have become extinct naturally No, they werenrsquot. The Cretaceous period was the third major period of the dinosaurs and they were doing really well. Some of the most well-known dinosaurs were around right about the time when the asteroid struck. It was also the age of the titanosaurs ndash the biggest dinosaurs to ever live. If that asteroid hadnrsquot crashed into the sea just north of Mexico then in all likelihood, things might have been very dferent and you might really have had a Tyrannosaursus in your garden or a Protoceratops in your playground. But remember, the asteroid did not kill all the dinosaurs . . .Have you ever been on expeditions to find dinosaur remains and where are the places most likely to find them I have. My favourite was when I went with Sir David Attenborough to Argentina to film the discovery and excavation of a true dino giant. The great thing about loving dinosaurs and living in the British Isles is that we have so many fossils of dinosaurs and other prehistoric species. There are certain beaches and riversides famous for fossils and you have a very good chance of finding the fossil bones of a prehistoric marine reptile or shark teeth or ammonite shells. You always have to go with an adult and thoroughly plan your trip because fossil hunting can be dangerous but itrsquos so much fun.Do you identy at all with lsquodinosaur expertrsquo characters on film or television There have been some well-known characters on TV who study dinosaurs but usually theyrsquore rubbish. Look at Ross from Friends . . . Irsquom pretty sure he couldnrsquot tell the dference between the head and butt of a Dreadnoughtus. Characters like that donrsquot inspire me. Real scientists are much better and inspire me every day. The men and women who spend their lives digging up fossils and investigating how these animals and plants lived are much cooler than a TV character.

title: music-fan-kevin-proves-39-s-popmaster
story: Kevin OrsquoDonnell stole the show when he appeared on PopMaster on BBC Radio .A score of  out of  was enough to win the quiz on Ken Brucersquos show.Kevin, who runs his own joinery and garden business, told the Courier: ldquoIt was something that I always wanted to do.ldquoI am right into my music and PopMaster is probably the premier music quiz in Britain.The -year-oldrsquos opponent managed a score of , with Kevin declared the winner and receiving the prize of a digital speaker in the shape of an old-style microphone.The prize has taken pride of place in Kevinrsquos West Barns home, with dozens of people getting in touch with him to offer their congratulations since the show was broadcast.He said: ldquoI met Bruce Springsteen in  in Newcastle and I think this is not quite up there with that but it is not far off.The popular radio quiz has been running for a number of years and each contestant is asked  questions based on popular music from the s through to the present day.He said: ldquoI have listened to Ken Bruce for a good  or  years and the last couple of years I have tried to get on the show.ldquoMy kids have always been saying to me to go.ldquoMy son, Conor, is the lead guitarist in The Tesla Coils and we are always discussing and talking about music.The music fan, who spoke to the Courier as he was en route to see American rock legends Kiss perform at the SSE Hydro in Glasgow, played down his achievement and said the questions simply fell in his favour.ldquoYou can get a possible  points thatrsquos the maximum you can score, said Kevin. ldquoThat is based on  questions and it is just general music knowledge. It just depends onit is for you.ldquoAll my stuff is s and s music andthe questions had been about the year  I would have got five out of !ldquoIt is really luck andthe questions are for you ndash it just happened that the questions were from my era.

title: connor-farrell-barber-stars-scottish-open-golf-renaissance-club
story: Bernd Wiesberger, who won the tournament at The Renaissance Club earlier this month, was among the professionals putting their feet up for a moment and getting a trim from Connor Farrell.The barber, who lives in Pencaitland, cut the hair of more than  golfers, caddies, management teams and sponsors.He said: ldquoYou see all these players on the television and then you get to have a good chat with them face to face. It was a good experience.ldquoWe were there and set up on the Monday and were Tuesday through Thursday, Friday cutting hair.ldquoWe were only supposed to be there on Tuesday and Wednesday but we got asked to stay on.ldquoWe reckon we did anywhere between  and  haircuts and it was all just complimentary. We did Bernd Wiesberger, who won the tournament, and Matt Wallace, who is ranked rd in the world.ldquoThey were all good guys. They are just normal people at the end of the day.ldquoWe talked about ious things ndash they wanted to know about good places to go eat in Edinburgh, ious local spots and seemed to like East Lothian and Edinburgh in general.Other golfers stepping into the hot seat included Lee Slattery, who finished tied for ninth at the competition, and West Lothianrsquos Stephen Gallacher.Former Ross High School pupil Connor, who is the owner and barber at Chaps Barber in Newcraighall, revealed that although the haircuts were complimentary, the golfers did offer generous tips and said: ldquoThey were pretty good ndash I cannot complain.Connor, who has been a barber for the last  months, got the chance through a family connection.His older sister Christy, , is dating North Berwick golfer Grant Forrest, who finished tied for rd at the event.Connor, , who plays golf at Longniddry Golf Club, was able to cheer Grant on.He said: ldquoThe European Tour got involved with Grantrsquos management company Bounce Sports.ldquoFrom there, they got the ball in motion and all the logistics of it.ldquoThese things take massive planning to get things done and it was quite a y process.ldquoIt took about two or three months to get it all finalised.

title: plea-save-former-dolphin-hotel-s-late
story: New le could be breathed into the former Dolphin Hotel, which included a bar and lounge on the ground floor.The bar closed in February  but the upstairs, which was used as a hotel, has not been in use for nearly  years.Developer The Dolphin InnLtd wants to ensure the building, on Dunbarrsquos Queenrsquos Road, has a future.Plans have been lodged with East Lothian Council for a hostel, complete with reception and cafe, on the ground floor.Under the proposals, the first floor would have four bedrooms, with three shower rooms and a family suite. The second floor would feature six bedrooms, with four bath or shower rooms, and the top floor acting as a managerrsquos flat.The developer has highlighted the poor state of the building and said that the first and second floors were ldquoseriously affected by dry rot and are unsafe.A ldquopriority of repairing the building and eradicating the advancing dry rot has been identied, with the developer keen to bring the building back into use ldquobefore itrsquos too late.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, told the Courier she had previously seen inside the building and it was ldquoin a terrible state of repair.She said: ldquoAnybody that wants to come in and invest high-quality renovation in Dunbar is to be welcomed.ldquoIt is wonderful that the building, which is so prominent, is in line for a facelt.ldquoMy understanding is that the client group is going to be aimed at walkers and surfers and, again, that would be warmly welcomed.Attempts had previously been made to see the building re-open as a hotel. However, there was ldquono interest from potential developers.A design and access statement, which is included within the planning application, notes: ldquoItrsquos quite possible there has been no demand for this property to be retained as a hotel due to competition in the immediate vicinity, namely The Royal Mackintosh Hotel on Station Road and the Hillside Hotel on Queenrsquos Road.Two years ago, Dunbar Trout Farm Ltd, was given permission to transform the building. Those plans, approved in August , included the creation of two shops and four flats.However, the design and access statement reads: ldquoSince this permission was obtained, despite evidence of marketing, there has been insufficient interest for its use as shops and flats.ldquoOur clientsrsquo proposal is to redevelop the building for use as a hostel, providing accommodation to visitors to Dunbar, [primarily] those who would take part in the large number of outdoor activities available within the area.ldquoA small flat-roofed single-storey extension to the side is proposed to provide associated laundry room.

title: charlotte-cowan-takes-west-highland-way-memory-dad-kenny
story: Charlotte Cowan, from North Berwick is completing the walk, over five days, beginning on September .The -year-old is raising money for the townrsquos Edington Cottage Hospital, the place where her dad spent his last week.Charlottersquos dad Kenny Cowan was a support worker but a joiner by trade.Having lost her mother when she was a baby, Kenny raised Charlotte and her brother as a single parent with help from her gran and other family members.Charlotte, who lives on Lochbridge Road, had a great relationship with her dad.ldquoI was very close to him and practically attached to his hip when I was little, I would go everywhere with him, she told the Courier.ldquoHe was such a genuinely lovely guy, no one had a bad word to say about him.ldquoHe was a big personality in the community and was so well known and loved by many.Kenny played bowls for Dirleton Bowling Club, darts in North Berwick and was an honorary member at the townrsquos rugby club for  years.He had been suffering with a bad back on and off for years, thinking it was sciatica.But in October last year the pain was getting worse, to the point he struggled to get out of bed.Two months later, Kenny was told he had stage four aggressive cancer in his spine which had spread and nothing more could be done.It was his last wish to be able to go to Edington Cottage Hospital before he died.ldquoUp until his very last day he had lots of visitors in to see him, Charlotte said.ldquoI donrsquot think [the Edington] had ever known as many visitors.ldquoHe was laughing and joking and listening to his beloved Runrig.Kenny died on January , aged .Charlotte said: ldquoIt was extremely hard to lose him. It was one of the hardest things to go through but we take comfort in the fact he said he would always be watching over us and we had time at the end to get to say goodbye to him and he knew how loved he was.She has always wanted to walk the West Highland Way, being a lover of the outdoors and a keen hiker.ldquoFamily and work commitments always seemed to get in the way or I just thought it would be too expensive, she said.ldquoWhen my dad passed away, I wanted to do something for him it kind of gave me the push to stop putting it off and actually go for it.ldquoI just want to do something big in his honour.ldquoI would just like to raise a bit of money for the hospital as it is a huge part of our community.ldquoI went there with my children when they were young, my gran and nana spent time in there, and my dadrsquos dad spent his last days in there also.ldquoMy dad was so well looked after that I just wanted to give something back, say thank you for looking after my dad and the community so well.In terms of the walk she is excited about the challenge ahead, saying: ldquoI canrsquot wait for the walk, I know itrsquos going to be hard doing it over five days, which is an average of  miles a day. I just hope my feet are up to the challenge!Charlottersquos training is going well, having already completed practice walks on her route to check out the terrain.She has also walked up Ben Nevis and completed the Three Lochs Way in one day.ldquoI havenrsquot managed any consecutive days walks yet as with kids and work itrsquos not easy to fit in, she said. ldquoBut when schools go back in August, I will have a month to get last bits of training in. I do feel ready, though, definitely.ldquoA bad blister could ruin it all or an injury, but hopefully neither will happen. Irsquove just got to be as prepared as possible and keep my fingers crossed for the rest.Charlotte is not doing the challenge solo, with three walking friends going along with her.She said: ldquoSupport has been great, everyone is getting behind me and wishing me well and helping with sponsors. I really appreciate any money raised.She said a special thank you to her step-mum Heather, who met Kenny when Charlotte was  and later married him, saying: ldquoShe has been a huge support for me through everything and I really want to thank her for that.On her goals, she said: ldquoJust being able to give something back is all Irsquod like to achieve.ldquoWe will be celebrating with a big gin at the end! The feeling of achievement and knowing I will have done my dad proud will be the best feeling, though. He would probably have called me crazy for doing this as he did for a few things I had done, but I know hersquod be proud and thatrsquos all I want to do.Donate at uk.virginmoneygiving CharlotteCowan or via the sponsor sheet at Charlottersquos work, Smithrsquos Pharmacy, North Berwick High Street.

title: dog-walker-stalker-sentenced-next-year
story: David Page followed and filmed the woman for over five years after he spotted her Labradoodle allegedly becoming overly-friendly with his greyhound-cross while out on a walk with his pet.Page, , used a GoPro camera, a mobile phone and a long-lens camera to intimidate the woman and her family when they took their dog out for walks in the town.The woman was forced to call the police and, after denying the allegations, Page, of Castle Street, eventually stood trial at Edinburgh Sherf Court last year.He was found guilty of causing fear and alarm to the woman and her family between January  and October  following the trial last July.He was also found guilty of a separate charge of using abusive language towards employees at East Lothian Council during a phone call on October , .Sherf Alistair Noble issued Page with a four-year non-harassment order banning him from approaching the woman and deferred full sentence to last week.However, when Page appeared in court, the sherf again deferred sentence on him to January next year.

title: great-music-tap-belhaven-brewery-hosts-300th-birthday-festival
story: The Belhaven th Birthday Bash features household names including Dougie Mac-Lean and Capercaillie, as well as up-and-coming bands such as Assynt and Kinnaris Quintet.The special event, which takes place in Dunbar on September , is being billed as a celebration of the best of Scottish music and beer.Gordon Muir, marketing controller and festival organiser, said: ldquoItrsquos not every year you get to mark a milestone as big as  years and so we wanted to celebrate this with Belhavenrsquos two loves, beer and Scottish music.ldquoBelhavenrsquos th Birthday Bash is the ultimate party for those fans and our loyal customers who enjoy nothing more than a few beers and great live music.ldquoWersquove plenty of things for the whole family to do, including storytelling and games for youngsters, selfie sessions and music masterclasses for the teens, and beer tastings and brewery tours for the adults.The main stage showcases the best in Scottish traditional music and top talent from Scotlandrsquos folk scene over the last three decades.Multi-award-winning Scottish contemporary folk band Breabach are joined by Highland outfit Tide Lines Niteworks, who have become renowned for their fusion of electronica and folk music and Elephant Sessions and Talisk ndash both winners of Belhavenrsquos annual bursary for innovation in Scottish music.Belhaven Breweryrsquos beers will be served from tap bars around the brewery grounds, including , a specially brewed birthday celebration pale ale. There will be food stalls and merchandise stalls.Meanwhile, the brewery gardens host family activities and music masterclasses.Gates open at am, with the first act taking to the stage at noon.The following day, the brewery is hosting an open day between am and pm.More information at belhaven birthday-bash

title: flexible-fundraiser-flips-along-belhaven-bay-help-charity
story: Hugh Panton literally went head over heels to help Friends of the Earth Scotland as he backflipped for a mile along Belhaven Bay.The -year-old, who lives just a mile from the beach, on Dunbarrsquos Bayswell Road, told the Courier: ldquoI was graduating from the University of Aberdeen and wanted to do something a bit special.ldquoI have always wanted to do a fundraiser event but never really had the time when I was at university.ldquoI decided I would do something that capitalises on my skills as a flipping enthusiast and had a couple of ideas.ldquoI thought maybe I would try to do , flips in five days or something and then it just came to me to try to do a mile of flips.ldquoAt the time, it sounded quite ridiculous but I really wanted to try it.The former Dunbar Grammar School pupil spent three days last month working his way from west to east along the picturesque beach for the challenge, which took him about  hours to complete.Hugh, who has started work as an assistant countryside ranger at the Loch of the Lowes Nature Reserve, near Dunkeld, was not the only one on the beach, as he attracted curious glances from onlookers.Hugh, who studied geography at university, managed to raise more than pound, and said: ldquoI would go down to the bay and I go to the very far end where there are not too many people.ldquoAfter a wee while training before doing the event, people would be walking by and their heads just slowly started following me down the beach.ldquoThere were horse riders as well and the horses did not like it at all and I would have to wait for them to pass.The flips were broken down into blocks of five or  so Hugh could keep his bearings, with the talented tumbler completing about  flips over each of the three days ndash  in total.Kerrigan Bell, development manager for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said: ldquoWersquore delighted that Hugh decided to raise much-needed funds.

title: airshow-lifeboat-fete-gullane-games-musselburgh-festival-spott-fete
story: The Courier has put together a list of five of the top things to do over Saturday and Sunday.Whether it is planes, boats, horses or much more, there is plenty to keep everyone occupied - eventhe weather isnt perfect.. Scotlands National AirshowBIG crowds are expected to flock to the National Museum of Flight at East Fortune on Saturday as Scotlandrsquos National Airshow takes place.And as well as all the aircraft initially announced, there are some exciting new additions to the line-up for the airshow, which takes place between am and pm, with the aerial displays set to commence from .pm.Despite todays poor weather, organisers said this morningthat the Met Office forecast "showednothing to prevent the Airshow going ahead today as planned".A Wildcat HMA  maritime attack helicopter,  Catalina flying boat and a  North American T Texan training aircraft are among the newbies.Joining them in their debut at the airshow are a Second World War Soviet Yakovlev Yak- fighter, a Westland Scout helicopter and a de Havilland Beaver utility aircraft.Also in the mix at the airshow are a Goodyear Corsair FG-D US wartime fighter bomber, Canadian T- Silver Star jet and an American P Thunderbolt Second World War fighter, while five members of the Wings Parachute Display Team drop in.As well as all the new additions, the aerial entertainment programme includes the RAFrsquos Supermarine Spitfire, Hawker Hurricane and Avro Lancaster from the RAF Battle of Britain Memorial Flight, as well as the modern-day Typhoon fighter jet.Aerobatic display team The Blades will take to the skies along with the AeroSuperBatics Wingwalkers, both performing some breathtaking tricks plus, much, much more.Tickets can be bought online, by calling    or on the gate on the day. title: dunbar-39-s-bear-statue-expected-place-later-year
story: Discussions surrounding an eye-catching piece of artwork near the A have been ongoing for several years.Original proposals suggested Apollo, the Greek and Roman god of the sun, could find a home on the Spott Road roundabout on the busy road.However, it was eventually decided a bear would be located nearby.Renowned Scottish artist Andy Scott ndash responsible for the Kelpies, near Falkirk ndash is the man behind the -foot bear, which will stand on its hind legs.Dunbar Community Council said it had received confirmation from applicants Hallhill Development Ltd that work should start towards the end of September and last for five weeks.East Lothian Council initially refused planning permission for the sculpture, which will be near the townrsquos Asda and McDonaldrsquos, but approval was finally given by the Scottish Government, with conditions from Transport Scotland.Ken Ross, from the applicants, previously told the Courier: ldquoThis piece of art will not only contribute to the emerging identity of Dunbarrsquos new gateway but has the potential to draw people into the area to find out more about John Muir.

title: revamped-aubigny-swimming-pool-revealed
story: Work got under way at the pool and health suite within the townrsquos Aubigny Sports Centre in April and ndash after a delay ndash the pool re-opened on Monday.Bill Axon, chief executive of enjoyleisure, which manages the sports centre, was confident visitors would be impressed with the changes.He said: ldquoIn my view, the only way to improve it would be to knock it down and start from scratch, which was not an option for us.ldquoIn terms of the amount of work and the quality of the work carried out, I think you will be absolutely delighted.Essential maintenance and interior deacutecor works have been carried out at the sports centre over several weeks.During the work, the two pools were drained, with a new light, bright ceiling covering the outdated wood cladding.New lighting, roofing works and ceiling and wall cladding work has been carried out surrounding the pool, with new lockers and other alterations in the changing rooms.Tiles were also given a thorough clean ahead of the re-opening.The new-look pool was revealed to enjoyleisure members and politicians last Friday.Among those attending the opening was East Lothian MP Martin Whitfield, along with Haddington and Lammermuir ward councillors Shamin Akhtar and Craig Hoy.Ms Akhtar was impressed with what she saw and said: ldquoI am delighted with the work.ldquoThe swimming pool looks absolutely fantastic.ldquoI think it will be really well received by the local community and I think it is going to be really well used.Ward colleague Mr Hoy agreed, saying: ldquoItrsquos fantastic to see the Aubigny pool re-opening and to see an entirely new look awaiting local residents.ldquoPools and sports centres arenrsquot just leisure facilities, they are le savers ndash helping our communities fight chronic diseases such as diabetes and heart disease.ldquoItrsquos vital we continue to invest in our gyms and swimming pools in East Lothian.The facility is one of East Lothianrsquos original sports centres and originally opened its doors as Haddington Swimming Pool in September . The site consists of a four-lane swimming pool and East Lothianrsquos only dedicated infant pool.Before the temporary closure, the facility welcomed about , bathers each week for swimming lessons, AquaFit classes, swimming club training, school and public use.

title: attempts-bring-bugs-back-john-muir-way
story: Charity Bugle Scotland aims to boost insect and bug numbers along or near the Dunbar-to-Helensburgh John Muir Way by encouraging wildflower-rich habitats at selected sites.A spokesperson for the charity said: ldquoThe UK has lost over  per cent of species-rich grassland since the s with dramatic declines in associated wildle including native bees, butterflies, hoverflies and beetles.Phase two of the pollinator project has recently been completed.There were  habitat sites in total that were seeded and rewilded, including four sites in East Lothian: Prestongrange Museum, by Prestonpans Cockenzie Primary School Longniddry Wood and at Waterston House, Aberlady.A new wildflower meadow was created on-site at Prestongrange Museum with help from the staff and volunteers Cockenzie Primary teachers and pupils lent a helping hand to create a bee garden in the school grounds and wildflower seeds were distributed to Waterston House to enhance their existing wildle garden and orchard. At Longniddry Wood, the charity worked with East Lothian Council to plant new bulbs and seeds.All of the habitats along or close to the John Muir Way were supported by funding from the Scottish Government and the Greggs Foundation, as well as the Central Scotland Green Network and the local authorities.Joanna Lindsay, conservation officer for Bugle Scotland said: ldquoCommunities all along the John Muir Way have contributed to enhancing their local greenspaces for wildle through this project and have learned about the importance of protecting our pollinator populations. Hopefully this time next year, walkers and cyclists using the route will enjoy seeing these sites buzzing with le.Roseanna Cunningham MSP, Environment Secretary, added: ldquoIrsquom pleased to support initiatives like this which help to create ideal habitats for our flora and fauna.

title: east-lothian-town-features-charlie-laidlaw-39-s-new-book
story: The Space Between Time uses Edinburgh, as well as North Berwick, in its story.Gullane author Charlie Laidlaw was pleased to say his second book ndash following on the heels of The Things We Learn When Wersquore Dead ndash had already attracted praise from reviewers.He said: ldquo[Before its official release] it had something like  reviews on Goodreads and all have been four or five stars.ldquoThat is encouraging because when you write a book you have confidence in it but you have no idea what kind of reaction other people will have to it.ldquoWhat  is encouraging is that the rights to an audio book and large print version have been snapped up.Actress Kate Okello, who starred in Stan  Ollie, will narrate the newly-released book.The Space Between Time, which has been published by Accent Press, tells the story of a young girl growing up in a dysal family and ultimately coming to terms with herself.Emma is the daughter of a beautul and loving mother, and her father is one of the most famous film actors of his generation.She is also the granddaughter of an eccentric and obscure Italian astrophysicist.But as her seemingly charmed le begins to unravel, and Emma experiences love and tragedy, she ultimately finds solace in her once-derided grandfatherrsquos theorem on the universe.The story offers the metaphor that everyone is connected, even to those that have been loved and not quite lost.Charlie, , says his books are ldquocharacter driven, with plans for a third book ndash Love Potions and Other Calamities ndash due to be released later this year.The Space Between Time has been three years in the making, with Charlie having to fit writing in around running his own media consultancy business in the county.He said: ldquoI carry around a notebook with me andan idea comes to me I will put it down.

title: tranent-woman-honoured-pope-services-catholic-church
story: Fiona Stewart, now resident of Banff in Aberdeenshire, was awarded the Benemerenti Medal for her  years of service to the church.Fiona has been singing at Tranentrsquos St Martinrsquos RC Church since she was eight, later playing guitar at services, and continued to do so throughout her teenage years and even came back on weekends when she studied at the University of Dundee.After moving to Banff in the early s, Fiona, , dedicated herself to her job as a senior solicitor at Aberdeen Council and to Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Banff ndash as secretary of the parish council, chair of the finance committee and  years as chief musician.This commitment to her church and its parish was recognised by the congregation, who nominated her.The nomination then went to the Bishop, who agreed, and took the request to Rome, where he collected the Papal award for Fiona, surprising her with it last month.She said: ldquoI had no idea this was happening. I was getting ready to play the guitar for the end of service when Father Colin Stewart presented me with the award.ldquoI was in shock, there was a large applause, and I was just shaking my head thinking lsquono wayrsquo!ldquoI was presented with a medal and a framed certicate from the Pope, and the congregation had made me a cake shaped like a guitar, which was really lovely. We had a tea party to celebrate.ldquoIrsquom still really taken aback. People kept saying to me lsquoit usually gets presented to really old people and rarely to womenrsquo so you can imagine how proud I am to have received it.ldquoMy parents are also really proud and astonished!ldquoI canrsquot wait for my visit to see them and come back to St Martinrsquos to play and sing, as I always do when Irsquom through. Itrsquos part of who I am, and I love coming back.Fionarsquos parents, William and Zuzanna Stewart, live on Tranent High Street.

title: east-lothian-foodbank-manager-peter-dicker-meets-queen
story: Peter Dicker, manager of the Tranent-based foodbank, and his we Linda Hamilton, area fundraiser for the NSPCC, were invited to the Royal Garden Party at the Palace of Holyroodhouse at the start of the month and found themselves unexpectedly in line to meet Her Majesty.Peter, of Port Seton, said: ldquoWe turned up at the party, and it was spectacular! I bumped into a friend of mine from The Royal Company of Archers ndash they serve as the Queenrsquos bodyguards when shersquos in Scotland ndash and we were chatting away when he said: lsquoDo you fancy meeting her, then rsquoldquoWe were gobsmacked as he took us to a line of people who were waiting to meet her and put us in it. We couldnrsquot believe it.ldquoShe was really lovely too. When she stopped, she asked me what I did, and I told her and she said: lsquoYou must be really busy at the moment.rsquo I answered: lsquoYes, with the introduction of Universal Credit, we have been very busy.rsquoldquoThen she asked: lsquoWhere does the food come from rsquo So I explained how the donation system worked and how we had just done a collection from the Tescos across East Lothian of , kilos of food and explained how we organised it and bagged it up and all the volunteers. She seemed really interested.ldquoShe spoke to Linda about her work with the NSPCC as she used to be its patron. Then she moved on.ldquoLinda and I just looked at each other and said: lsquoWow! We just met the Queen!rsquoPeter, who has been manager of the foodbank, on Civic Square, since , admitted: ldquoIt took days for my we and I to get our heads around it. We were so excited.ldquoI said to Linda on the way home: lsquoShe had such wise eyes.rsquo I mean, imagine all she has seen and everyone she has met. It really was wonderful.The Queen hosts four garden parties a year ndash three at Buckingham Palace and one at Holyrood ndash with more than , people attending in total.

title: top-fringe-talent-appear-brunton
story: Top Fringe talent to appear at The BruntonDougie MacLean: Photo: Rob McDougall. title: lighting-project-complete-historic-st-mary-39-s-parish-church
story: Substantial work was carried out at St Maryrsquos Parish Church over the first six months of the year to install a modern lighting system.A total of pound, has been spent on the scheme, which was completed last month.Stewart Meikle, an elder at the historic Haddington church, said the new lighting system was already making a massive dference.He said: ldquoThat is the project complete.ldquoThe benefits are ious: the interior of the building has been transformed, with the lighting highlighting all the features, the archways, the ceiling etc. We are also saving a lot of energy and making it easier to maintain.The improvements have been in the planning for several years. Mr Meikle paid tribute to AB Lighting and Nicholson Bros for their input in making the project a reality.Funding has come from a iety of sources.Mr Meikle told the Courier: ldquoIt has come from a mix of the churchrsquos own money from the sale of the manse, some of that has been allocated.ldquoThere was a lot of local fundraising held, including an art exhibition, and we have had personal donations from a fair few people.ldquoWe had grant applications from Viridor, WREN are providing money, and Tyne Esk LEADER are pitching in. There were ious small grants from Persimmon and Tesco Bags of Help.Work started in January, with the scheme split into two phases, which limited entry and exit from the church.Mr Meikle said the plan had been to get the work carried out in the first half of the year to ensure the building was looking at its best for the Lammermuir Festival, which takes place in September, and Armistice Day in November.He added: ldquoIt is pretty impressive.ldquoWe have had only a positive reaction from people in the church.ldquoLammermuir Festival are delighted with the lighting and we have not had anyone say a bad word about it.The Very Rev Dr John Cairns, interim moderator at St Maryrsquos, also paid tribute to all those involved.He said: ldquoMany congratulations to all the team who have seen this through to completion, from the contractors to our own property and finance folk.ldquoAbove all, a particular debt is owed to Stewart Meikle, for without his commitment and drive it would not have been achieved so effectively and timeously.ldquoThe lighting scheme was an ambition of [former minister, the late] Jenner Macrae and, like so much  she gave in her ministry, provides us with a heritage and a firm base from which to move into the next phase of St Maryrsquos le.

title: housebuilder-told-apologise-ormiston-residents
story: The housing firm was hauled before East Lothian Councils planning committee after it was discovered they had created a new access and put a sales caravan in place on the Limeylands site, in Ormiston, without seeking approval.And despite making a public apology for the move, councillors refused to give the changes planning permission instead rejecting a retrospective application and giving them two months to remove it.Councillors criticised Barratt for failing to engage with the local community and creating a feeling within local residents that there was a "lack of respect" for them.They were also told a sub contractor employed by the firm had mistakenly chopped down a mature tree which had not been in their plans causing further upset in the village.Councillor Willie Innes told the housebuilders that while he believed their actions were "misadventure" rather than "malicious" they could not be allowed to go unnoticed.And he warned the firm the situation in the village was "really a mess".Residents in Ormiston had opposed the plans to build  homes at the site off Limeylands Road, when they were first put forward five years ago.East Lothian Council rejected the original plans but the housing firm took their case to the Scottish Government Report who overturned the decision allowing them to go ahead with the housing.The planning committee were told that Barratt had now created a car park and sales caravan at the site with an access from the road, none of which were included in the approved plans.Mr Innes said: "What Barratt needs to understand is that they are creating a feeling in the commuity that Barratt does not respect them."The commuity opposed the original application and Barratt are holding it against them."I do not think that is the case, I think it is misadventure rather than malice. Barratt need to get round the table with the community."Jason Watt, from Barratt, told the committee that the company apologised for any concerns it has caused and was looking into improving its communication with the local community councily.He said the access created for the sales caravan was temporary and only in place while construction of the first home was carried out for health and safety reasons.However Mr Innes urged fellow committee members to reject a application approving the changes made saying Barratt needed to go back to the community and "rebuild its relationship" with them.The committee voted to reject the application by six votes to four.

title: craft-show-slot-joy-talented-jeweller-hannah-scott
story: Jeweller Hannah Scott will join  others in Edinburgh between next Fridayand August  to showcase her work.The second floor of White Stuff on the Capitalrsquos George Street will play home to a iety of craft and design pieces all made in Scotland, from cushions and textiles to jewellery, ceramics and glass.Hannah grew up near the beach in Cornwall but now lives in Musselburgh.She graduated from the Royal College of Art and Glasgow School of Art.She gathers inspiration for her work through maps, cityscapes and textures of the shoreline.Her most recent lsquoCoastline Collectionrsquo allows people to tell their own stories and capture their memories.Also on offer at the Craft Scotland Summer Show are maker-led workshops, which include hand weaving, willow weaving and paper folding.August  will see people being shown traditional bookbinding, while six days later, on August , attendees can learn how to create colour, pattern and textures on fabrics.Children aged  to  can get involved in young maker workshops, a new element for .Irene Kernan, Craft Scotland director, said: ldquoAt Craft Scotland we are incredibly privileged to be surrounded by beautul craft and engage with talented makers on a daily basis.ldquoKnowing the wealth of amazing work being made in Scotland, wersquore excited to be able to share so much of that at this yearrsquos show.ldquoWith the largest number of makers ever taking part this year,the Summer Show is the best place to see whatrsquos fresh and new in contemporary craft and the best place to discover new talents who are exploring interesting materials and themes.ldquoItrsquos particularly encouraging to see so many makers who will show their work with us for the first time.The Craft Scotland Summer Show is free to enter more information can be found at craftscotland.org

title: dr-punam-krishan-reality-life-scottish-gp
story: The brief transcript, which Dr Krishan posted on Twitter, read: "Patient: I dont want an Asian doctor. Receptionist: She is Scottish. Patient: She doesnt look Scottish. Receptionist: What do Scottish people look like  Silence. Appointment card taken. So proud of my team."The tweet went viral and Dr Krishan, , received messages from as far afield as Argentina, Colombia, Ghana, India, Canada and Australia. Six months later, she remains blown away by the reaction."It had an engagement of . million impressions across the world," she says. "I didnt expect it to be as global. It was such an overwhelmingly positive response."Dr Krishan, who works as a GP in the East End of Glasgow, has gained a raft of followers who enjoy her warmth, candour and thought-provoking posts on social media where she is an impassioned proponent about the importance of kindness."I always say to my medical students and trainees that learning the science is the easy bit," she says. "We can learn from textbooks, absorb the knowledge and spout that out. But it means nothingit is not delivered with compassion and care."It is a theme we come back to several times in our conversation. Hearing Dr Krishan talk about her love of being a GP, it is hard to believe she almost never took that path.The eldest of two daughters, she grew up in Glasgow and describes herself as being "raised on curry and Irn Bru". Her Indian-born parents arrived from Punjab in the late s. "We grew up in my dads corner shop," she says. "It was ingrained in us that education was the key to freedom. You were either going to be a doctor, lawyer, accountant or a failure."Medicine became an early front-runner thanks to her childhood family GP. "He was very much a role model for me from a young age because he was the core of our community," she says. "Everyone knew thatDr Kauser saw them, they would be OK."A seed was planted for the future Dr Krishan. "I loved the idea of being able to help and heal people in a community setting," she says. "I admired him and knew education was a must, but then I hit school and everything I loved was wildly dferent to the sciences."I enjoyed history and language and music and drama. I wanted to study English Lit, but I was edged into choosing medicine. My mum couldnt understand why I wanted to study English or drama.":Why we love Glasgows street artHer mother would regularly walk past the University of Glasgow, gaze longingly at its towering spire and tell her daughters that they would one day study there. "It was almost like she manested it," says Dr Krishan, a smile in her voice."It was one of her unfinished dreams. My mum had an arranged marriage. She was going to study medicine in India but couldnt because she came to Scotland to be married. Both my sister and I went to the University of Glasgow to study medicine. We are both GPs in Glasgow."On paper it sounds like a picture-perfect le trajectory, yet Dr Krishan reveals that in her teens, there was a point when she went off the rails."I was a nightmare for my mum and dad," she recalls. "Growing up, I was confused about where I truly belonged. Our summer holidays were always spent in India. I had very much my Indian existence at home, but all my friends were Caucasian."There were a lot of restrictions and being told: You cant do this you cant do that ndash what will the aunties think  which I found frustrating. I was always testing the boundaries. I got into trouble at school and was suspended on a couple of occasions."When I failed all my exams in third year ndash I got straight sevens in my Standard Grades ndash my mum said she was going to send me to India to finish my studies. She had lost hope. I was given one last chance to turn it around. That was a wake-up call."Dr Krishan, who attended Notre Dame High School, knuckled down and achieved the grades to study medicine. "It was after I became a doctor that I started to feel liberated," she attests. "Then I really felt my wings unclipped after I became a mum."The birth of her son Aarish, now six, provided another watershed moment. "I ended up on a ventilator in intensive care," she says. "My family were told that I didnt have long to live. What happened to me was a complete out-the-blue crisis point in le that gives you a scare."She had suffered a postpartum haemorrhage. "It was a freak, bleed-out episode," explains Dr Krishan. "I went into heart and lung failure, developed clotting issues and widespread sepsis."Afterwards, Dr Krishan experienced a le-changing epiphany. "Everybody around me tried to medicalise me," she says. "Everything was about maybe you need this tablet, when actually all I wanted was support and space to heal. I didnt want drugs to do that."I started exercising and eating food to nourish myself inside and out. It is amazing what insights being on the other side of that desk can give you. I ed to work a completely dferent doctor."Holistic care is something Dr Krishan regularly applies in her work as a GP. "I see a lot of poverty and patients living in social isolation, as well as drug misuse. It is quite a challenging population but equally it is a place where you can really make a big dference."Around  to  per cent of the things I see as a GP are lestyle-related medical problems. It has become my passion to focus more on the lestyle habits that people form, rather than just the -minute appointment model which is: How can I get you in and out  Can I give you a drug "She takes her patients on "Lidl walks" to share tips on what foods to avoid and how to make healthier choices. Last year, Dr Krishan and a colleague set up Glasgow Wellbeings, a public group where they share their "health hacks", which has grown to more than  members.Dr Krishan is married to a fellow GP. "He started off as an orthopaedic surgeon, but you cant live with me and not become a GP," she jokes. Her enthusiasm is clearly infectious, then. "I would sell it in a jarI could."She is currently writing a childrens health book and will make her presenting debut in a forthcoming BBC Scotland medical documentary series due out later this year. Dr Krishan also hopes to pen a memoir about her experiences working as a GP."My dream is to write books to help as many people as I can through informed and reflective storytelling in a bid to inspire and empower them along their wellness journeys. I want to bring my Eastern heritage and the wisdom that holds into my scientic Western practice.":Why we love Glasgows street artThe traditional role of a doctor advocates an evidence-based scientic approach to clinical care. It is important to maintain professional boundaries, yet Dr Krishan strongly believes that patients need compassion too.Such as instinctively hugging a patient who had been diagnosed with advanced bowel cancer. Two weeks later, after the man passed away, his family visited her to say thank you and tell her how much that hug had meant to him."Le has been kind to me in that it has taught me lessons ndash sometimes in the most brutal ways," she says. "I have been the vulnerable mum and I have ageing parents, so I understand the pain that brings. I have also lived as a troubled teenager trying to find my identity."With this man who was dying of cancer, I was helpless. There was nothing I could do. He knew that and I could see the fear in his eyes. It just felt so intuitive [to hug him] becausethat was my father or grandfather, I would have wanted somebody to reach out and say: Its OK, Im here for you."Follow Dr Punam Krishan on Twitter and Instagram at @DrPunamKrishan

title: mps-use-brexit-reset-farm-funding
story: The cross-party group of MPs said leaving the EU was a chance to fix problems in the current formula, which sees low funding for Scottish farms and crofts under the Common Agricultural Policy .The committee urged the Government to drop an ldquooutdated method that ldquofailed to reflect Scotlandrsquos unique agricultural conditions and practices.It recommended a new system linking funding to a nationrsquos proportion of less favoured land, with farmers and crofters working in challenging conditions receiving the most support.The UK Governmentrsquos pilot seasonal agriculture scheme was also criticised for not providing enough workers to address Scotlandrsquos agricultural workforce crisis.MPs called for it to cover , workers, and a scrapping of application and visa interview fees to open the scheme to all motivated workers, not just those who can afford to apply.SNP committee chairman Pete Wishart said: ldquoScotland has some of the most challenging farming environments in the UK and yet Scottish farming is the cornerstone of Scottish food and drink industry and farms and crofts remain central to many thriving communities.ldquoIt is nonsensical that funding through the CAP has not recognised these challenging conditions so my committee is calling on the UK Government to take Brexit as an opportunity to rewrite the rules of agricultural funding. A countryrsquos environmental conditions and situation should be a central tenet of its funding settlement.ldquoIf the UK Government accepts this principle, Scotland will be likely to receive a signicantly greater proportion of funding, allowing the agricultural sector to realise its full potential.Mr Wishart added: ldquoThe Government must also do much more to resolve the workforce crisis on Scottish farms. ldquoThe seasonal workers pilot must be quadrupled in sizeit has any chance of addressing this.ldquoThe uncertainty surrounding no-deal tarfs and future of geographical indications must also be resolved so Scotland can be confident its agriculture sector will be protected and enhanced post-Brexit.ldquoMy committeersquos report makes workable recommendations that the UK Government should implement to give Scottish farmers and crofters cause for optimism about the future of agriculture post-Brexit.

title: two-people-trapped-shetland-gas-explosion
story: One, a pensioner on her eighties, has been rescued and taken to hospital in Lerwick.The explosion took place in mid-afternoon at Ockragarth nearBrae.Police said they had attended a house fire just before . in the afternoon in the Ockragarth area of Brae.:Two arrested after woman found dead in ShetlandWhile investigations are ongoing, the cause is believed to have been a gas explosion. title: poll-finds-big-public-support-holiday-let-crackdown
story: The YouGov survey found  per cent of respondents who expressed a view supported new taxes on holiday lets, and % thought all short-term landlords should be registered.More than three-fths thought all or most of the extra tax income should be spent on local housing.It comes after more than , people signed an online petition calling for limits on lets.Long-term private landlords must register with their local council, but holiday let landlords taking bookings through website such as Airbnb are not required to do so.The poll was commissioned by the campaign organisation  Degrees, and comes just a week after the close of a Scottish Government consultation on holiday lets.The group want the Government to empower councils to cap holiday let numbers, levy taxes on holiday lets, and require holiday let landlords to register like other landlords.Megan Bente Bishop of Living Rent, Scotlandrsquos Tenantsrsquo Union, said: ldquoPeople know all too well what the current lack of regulation on holiday lets means for communities.ldquoIt means families forced out, communities ripped apart and ever fewer homes for people who want to live and work in Scotland.ldquoAt the same time, the landlords who own these properties are making a killing. This urgently has to change, or the damage will be irreversible.Chloe Lawson of  Degrees said: ldquoMore than , people across Scotland have signed a petition demanding that the Scottish Government stop holiday lets destroying our communities.ldquoThis polling shows the vast majority of people across Scotland also back that demand. The ball is now in the governmentrsquos court: will they stand up for communities across the country Green MSP Andy Wightman, who has long campaigned for tough controls on holiday lets in Edinburgh, said: ldquoThere is a clear case for all owners of short term lets to pay their fair share of tax to local authorities. This poll again shows that there is huge public support to control the spread of short term lets.ldquoMy research shows that the City of Edinburgh Council loses out on over pound. million in uncollected non-domestic rates due to short term lets annually. This means that the owners of short term lets enjoy hefty profits and an uplt in the value of their property while not contributing a single penny to local services, all the while my constituents are left to deal with the anti-social behaviour which often accompanies such lets.SNP housing minister Kevin Stewart said: ldquoWhile short-term lets can have a positive impact and help boost the tourism economy across all areas of Scotland, we know they can also create challenges for some communities. Thatrsquos why we want to ensure that short-term lets are regulated appropriately.ldquoWe are grateful for the large number of responses we received to our recent consultation, which we will now carefully consider before publishing an analysis and considering our next steps.ldquoWe are committed to working with local authorities to give them the powers they need to balance the unique needs of their communities with wider economic and tourism interests.

title: sheriff-rejects-20k-claim-amorous-bull
story: Kathleen and Bernard Allen sought pound, from David and Janine Hargreaves following the excursion in Kirkibost on the island of Great Bernera off Lewis.The pregnancy only came to light months later when a surprise calf was born displaying the distinctive black and white marking of its Belted Galloway father compared to the reddish colouring of Kathleen Allenrsquos Highland cattle.The Allens wanted compensation for damaged fences, their herdrsquos premium health status being comprised, losses from pedigree sales and for ldquodistress and inconvenience.But they ldquowilfully refused to fix their own damaged fence allowing cattle to stray between crofts, ruled Sherf David Sutherland.Crucially, it was entirely possible it was the Allenrsquos heer who did the actual roaming by going to the neighbouring field and liaising with the bull.ldquoAny of the losses claimed byarose out of his failure to maintain the fence,ldquo concluded the sherfIn his judgement, the sherf said it was ldquoclear during the civil court case in Stornoway Sherf Court that this was a neighbour disputeldquo as opposed to anything .The sherf pointed out the Scottish Land Court previously ruled Mr Allen should maintain the fence under a historic ldquosensible and fair arrangement between villagers.The fence was Mr Allenrsquos responsibility but he refused upkeep it.ldquoI was a little unhappy to hear that whilemaintained that the cattle belonged to her, she did not tell the accreditation authority that, who therefore put her husband down as the accredited owner, said the sherf.He added: ldquoI fully understand that a croft can only be in the name of a single person but I think Mrs Allen could have been more forthright with the authorities when she was endeavouring to obtain accredited status for the herd.Sherf Sutherland was ldquoless than impressed to learn Mrs Allen failed to tell the premium health authority about the invasion of unaccredited cattle and also secret from them the birth of the Belted Galloway calf, despite these incidents being in ldquoserious breach of their regulations.She presented an ldquoexaggerated and unreliableldquo case and her evidence was ldquonot as credible or reliable as I would have wished, he stressed.On the other hand, the Hargreaves ldquofulfilled their duty of care and took ldquofair and reasonable steps to ensure that their cattle did not transgress and they cannot be ldquocriticised in any way.The ldquounwanted impregnation compromised the premium heath status of her herd, said Mrs Allen while giving evidence.For  hours a day she was forced to stand watch to prevent the bull ldquoinvading her croft as it repeatedly broke post-and-wire fences in the summer of  and  to get to her heers, she said in evidence.At one point she ldquofound the bull chasing my cow around the field, after it jumped a fence.Police were called some  times to sht the marauding animal back to its own owners.At the peak of the visits, ldquoalmost daily my animals were penned up for four to five days in a bid to keep them safe, she added.A pound, eight foot high fence - dubbed Jurassic Park - was installed ldquoto stop their cattle from coming onto my croft.In the witness box, David Hargreaves said the electric fence retaining his bull - called Ozzie - was vandalised  times letting him roam onto the adjacent holding.He described a terrying battle between Ozzie and the Allenrsquos hired Highlander stud, called Calum Ruadh - identied by his ear tag as  - amid a lot of ldquounusual noises.But Ozzie was ldquogouged and bleeding and pretty much defenceless as he has no horns and is two thirds the size of the Highlander.

title: judge-society-happy-not-wealthy
story: The merest glimpse of the lives of moguls, oligarchs and millionaires tells you that. Are the faces staring out from the pages of glossy magazines shining with wellbeing  They might be tanned, toned, and expensively exfoliated, butany of these iniduals has a heart full of joy, it is unlikely to be as a result of their lestyle.In a recent talk, Nicola Sturgeon made an appeal to commonsense, stating what, deep down, most of us already know. She claims that when calibrating a countryrsquos standing and success, gross domestic product is not the most accurate measure. Not least among the misleading factors when using GDP as a guide is that its figures ignore unpaid carersrsquo work, yet put a value on illegal drug consumption. Just as worryingly, says Ms Sturgeon, ldquoIt values activity in the short term that boosts the economy eventhat activity is hugely damaging to the sustainability of our planet in the longer term.The First Ministerrsquos laudable aspiration is that ldquothe objective of economic policy should be collective wellbeing ndash how happy and healthy a population is, not just how wealthy a population is. Hoping to establish a fairer and truer scale of assessment, she is collaborating with the prime ministers of New Zealand and Iceland ndash women all, in charge of countries geographically on the fringes, who are prepared to challenge convention.Cynics might, of course, say that Ms Sturgeon is simply laying the groundwork for another independence bid, in which those predicting dire financial consequences will be brushed off as old-fashioned and out of touch by placing too much emphasis on our economic prowess. Yet with Brexit, not just economists but rabid Leavers acknowledge that orce from the EU will cause financial shockwaves. Clearly, this is a risk they think worth running. By the same token, idealists north of the Border, who want us to exit from the UK, often say that the possibility of diminished economic performance after independence would not in itself be a deal breaker. There are bigger issues at stake.That argument is for another day. At this point, were Scotland to become a pioneer in putting a fairer society ahead of a more affluent one, this would represent nothing less than a second enlightenment. The inequalities in health and housing, education and attainment that are nakedly apparent all around us, are shaming for one of the wealthiest countries in the world. No matter how much those at the top make, or how vibrant our financial markets, poverty and desperate hardship for too many people persists. Itrsquos tempting to think that those who see GDP and similar indices as telling the whole story have also embraced the biblical creed that the poor will always be with us ndash in other words, there is nothing we can do about their plight.While the SNP has not been far-sighted or proactive enough to combat the recent shocking rise in drug-related deaths, many of them linked to deprivation and hopelessness, nevertheless Ms Sturgeon and the like-minded leaders with whom she is allied, have a strong social conscience. If the message that money is only part of the equation takes hold, it could potentially prove a turning point for the way all rich societies see, and regulate, themselves.Naturally therersquos a danger when writing disparagingly about high-income earners of appearing either green-eyed or preachy. Despite spending a childhood in the pews, hearing how the widowrsquos mite was as valuable as the millionairersquos cheque, and that those who are hard up today will be blessed with eternal treasures in the hereafter, I nevertheless know that no pair of rose-tinted spectacles can make a terrying bill, an unattainable holiday or too-expensive winter coat, one bit easier to bear. As Mae West put it bluntly: ldquoIrsquove been rich and Irsquove been poor, and rich is better.When it comes to wellbeing, you donrsquot need a carbon monoxide monitor to recognise that the air in Stornoway or St Abbs is far better for us than that in the throbbing financial hearts of Edinburgh or Glasgow, or for that matter Tokyo and New York. Wellbeing consists of something way beyond liquidity, location, or assets. Those in their gated communities, who store their Cartier watches in a vault, have cut themselves off from the rest of society. Is that really enviable  This is not to say they might not be really decent, kind-hearted people who give generously to good causes. Perhaps some of them are. But no matter how open-handed they appear to be, money creates a spiralling gulf between the haves and the have-nots, and sometimes cause rts much closer to home, as family lawyers will attest.Far from solving the problem by capitalistsrsquo pet theory of ldquotrickle-down, too much capital at the top of society actually entrenches inequality. Thus, the endless pursuit of higher incomes, pricier properties, competitive conspicuous consumption, whether at a personal or national level, is intrinsically unhealthy. Once you believe that the GDP graph should show an inexorable year-on-year increase, you become blinkered. This is as true, I suspect, for those running the country as for the inidual.Hunger for amassing hundreds of thousands of pounds, and the power that comes with it, is a recipe for potential disaster. It is psychologically and spiritually corrosive. Slowing the Gradgrind pursuit of ever-greater productivity, focusing on more nourishing and longer-lasting priorities, is a way of calling time on the fallacy that the bottom line is all that matters, and that cash is king. It is a way of taking an ethical stance, and saying enough is enough. How to calculate what constitutes enough, of course ndash be it income, savings, love, leisure, charity, you name it ndash is even harder than measuring happiness.Read more: Scotlands history has lain in the British shadow for too long
